item.title: Resolving with dnsimple
item.author: support@taskwarrior.org (Taskwarrior Team)
item.description:
Since a couple of weeks ago the resolving of our hostnames and domains is handled via services of dnsimple. They are kindly enough to sponsor the taskwarrior project. We will not only profit from the developer-friendly management console but in particular from the powerful API to handle our DNS tasks when we move towards our new CI system flod2.
Please check them out under https://dnsimple.link/resolving-taskwarrior.

description.p: Flod2 is now being rolled out for testing. This is a CI system rewrite that eliminates build server daemons and the pull model. This will allow greater use of virtual machines, and more automation. For example, we will now be able to automatically generate coverage reports and snapshot tarballs, based on build characteristics.

item.title: Using Dates Effectively
item.author: support@taskwarrior.org (Taskwarrior Team)
item.description:
A task does not require a due date, and can simply be a statement of need:
$ task add Send Alice a birthday card
However this is exactly the kind of task can benefit from having a due date, and perhaps several other dates also.
There are several dates that can decorate a task, each with its own meaning and effects. You can choose to use some, all or none of these, but like all Taskwarrior features, they are there in case your needs require it, but you do not pay a performance or friction penalty by not using them.

item.title: Doc: Duration Formats
item.author: support@taskwarrior.org (Taskwarrior Team)
item.description:
Taskwarrior supports duration values. In the core, durations are used directly in one place - the 'recur' attribute, used for recurring tasks. For example, here is a recurring task that recurs every monday:
"$ task add Take out the trash due:monday recur:weekly"
The value 'monday' is interpreted as 'next monday', and the value 'weekly' is interpreted as a 7-day duration.

item.title: Design Doc: Hooks v2 API
item.author: support@taskwarrior.org (Taskwarrior Team)
item.description:
To support an evolving Hooks API, Taskwarrior must provide hook scripts with a mechanism for determining which version of the Hooks API is prividing the context for the script.
It is anticipated that in future versions, new events will be added, and changes to the interfaces will occur. A hook script needs to act according to the API version, otherwise it risks incompatibility with Taskwarrior.
The interfaces define what is provided as standard input, and what is expected on standard output. With v2 there will also be command line arguments provided to the script.
